Dear Ms. Thomas-Cloud:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
December 18, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP)
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400. 12324.2. b Reevaluation
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as determined by
observation of, and interviews with, each member of the
household and each social service worker who has had children
placed in the home during the last licensing period.
Three of eight active foster home case files reviewed were missing information in the
report. Specific information missed was the individual household members
relationship to the caregiver.
R 400.12324.8 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Two of eight active foster home case files that required reevaluations during this
period under review (PUR) were not provided to the Department within the required
time frame. This involved the reports being signed by the agency 13 and 10 days
respectively prior to the end date of the license.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2020 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 3/11/2020
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have the Updated Service
Plan (USP) completed timely. This involved three USPs, 8, 2, and 2 days late
respectively.

R 400.12502 Program statement.
An agency must have policies and procedures that comply, at a
minimum, with the requirements in the rules that correspond to
the subsections. If an agency’s policies and procedures exceed
the minimum requirements specified in the rule, the agency is
required to follow the written policies and procedures. An
agency that does not follow its own policies may be cited as
being in violation of this rule.
Two of three open independent living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the agency provided their program statement to the youth in
care.
R 400.12502 Policy and procedures.
An agency must have a specific policy for each of the
subsections identified in the rule. The minimum content of the
policy is specified in the rules.
If a private agency is under contract to the Department of Health
and Human Services and agrees, as part of the contract, that
DHHS policies and procedures will be followed, the agency
must follow those policies. An agency may also have policies
that exceed the minimum standards set forth in the rules. If an
agency’s policies exceed the minimum standards, the agency is
accountable for following their own policies.
Two of three open independent living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the agency provided their policies and procedures to the youth in
care.

DHHS Policy FTM PRACTICE GUIDANCE
722-06B – Page
13
The DHHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information, needs,
strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the safety plan,
and any recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every
FTM.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of the
DHHS-1105 in the case file. This involved two missing DHHS-1105 for the
documented FTMs taking place.

FOM 722-16
Page 11

FOM 722-06H
page 15-16
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within

Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that

entries being timely for a 76% rate of compliance.
Three of three open independent living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that each social work contact was entered in a timely manner. This
involved 20 of 24 entries being timely for an 83% rate of compliance.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 Two of the corrective action plans associated with Special Evaluations completed
by the agency on two foster homes did not have documentation of the process
for monitoring the completion of the CAP. The CAPs were appropriate with the
exception of missing documentation of a process for measuring over-site. This
was discussed with the agency.
 Several files contained information uploaded but not consistently in the same
location with each file. This issue was discussed with the agency and they will
look into methods to make changes.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The agency informed the consultant that the position of the compliance officer
is a dual position. It was suggested that this position be a full-time compliance
position to ensure that the agency is in full compliance with the licensing
rules, contract, and policy requirements. The agency was receptive to this
information.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first special investigation (2019C0212040) requiring a corrective action plan was
initiated on 7/24/19 and involves the following allegations. It is alleged that an
agency staff accessed unauthorized MiSACWIS records. The allegations were found
to be true and the following was the action of the approved CAP. The staff involved
in the allegations was terminated from her position and security and confidentiality
guidelines, rules and penalties will be reviewed with staff at the next unit meeting on
April 13, 2020. This was verified to have occurred during this inspection. The agency
provided a copy of the meeting agenda that took place on March 10, 2020 and
covered the aspects outlined in the CAP.
9

The second special investigation (2021C0212004) requiring a corrective action plan
was initiated on 11/7/19 and involves the following allegations. It is alleged that a
foster child was bitten by the foster family dog when the agency knew there were
issues with the dog’s aggression. Additional finding involved the agency not
sufficiently assessing the foster home during a special evaluation. The allegation
and additional finding were found to be true and the approved CAP involved the
following: Staff responsibilities: Training for all licensing and foster care workers
provided by the Program Manager during the individual staff meeting in March 2020.
“Child Safety in Foster Home will be on the Foster Care Supervisor’s agenda for the
next 12 months. Special Evaluation: The agency is to develop a new procedure for
all families with pets in their homes which will be reviewed and signed by the
families. Training for licensing worker involving documenting all questions during a
Special Evaluation conducted by the Program Manager. The Licensing Supervisor
will document compliance with this action during annual and renewals. This was
verified to have occurred during this inspection. The agency provided documentation
of the training in the form of meeting agendas and a copy of the changed
policy/procedure that covers the topic outlined in the CAP.
The third required corrective action plan involved the agency’s 2020 Annual
licensing inspection.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Field Analyst interviewed five licensed homes and two unlicensed relative
homes. There was one safety concern identified.
Safety Concern #1:
There was a smoke detector in the home not working properly. The Analyst heard the
detector beeping during his interview with the family.
Resolution: Documentation provided by the agency and documented in the
MiSACWIS system indicated that the “Caseworker conducted a home visit on
12/11/20 at 5:00 p.m., viewed the smoke detector in question, observed the caregiver
replace the battery and documented it fully operational”. The agency also provided a
photo of the working detector.
Fifteen interviews were conducted with staff ranging from the Program Manager to
Foster Care Case Managers. Each reporting that the agency is supplying their needs
to work in the COVID-19 environment in a safe way. They also report that many of
their social work contacts are completed virtually but that they are able to keep up
with the needs of their families and youth. All workers report that their supervisors are
knowledgeable and keep in a high level of communication with them. They feel
supported and believe that the agency is working in the best interest of the families
and youth. All interviewed agreed that it has been difficult during the COVID-19, but
they have been able to meet the demands of the families and youth.
10

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
